summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Oct. 7, 2010.

headline: Immigrant Population Edges Down
summary: The percentage of San Franciscans born outside of the country declined over the past few years, in a sign of how the recession affected the flow of immigrants into the Bay Area.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 7

headline: It Takes All Kinds
summary: A look at some of the physical outliers participating in this year's Major League Baseball playoffs.

headline: Inspection Leads to Grounding of NYPD Copter
summary: An inspection of the New York Police Department helicopter fleet following a forced emergency water landing of a police helicopter on patrol during President Barak Obama's visit to New York during the United Nation's General Assembly meeting two weeks ago has caused the grounding of a second $12 million copter, police say.

headline: Stimulus Checks Sent to Dead
summary: The Social Security Administration sent about 89,000 stimulus payments of $250 each to dead and incarcerated people—but almost half of them were returned.

headline: S&P Cautions on Debt Cost of Aging Populations
summary: Government debts will surge in coming decades if action isn't taken quickly to cut the cost of paying pensions and providing health care to aging populations, Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said.

headline: Comebacks and Co-Conspirators
summary: From Nancy Wilson to John Pizzarelli and Kenny Barron, this weekend offers a plethora of jazz virtuosity.

headline: Betting on Casinos
summary: Singaporeans wrestled for years with whether to green-light its first two casinos, which opened with international fanfare earlier this year. But the resorts appear to be a huge success, at least so far.

headline: Health-Care Law Challenge Rejected
summary: A Michigan federal judge upheld the constitutionality of a key provision of the recently enacted federal health-care law that requires individuals to maintain health-insurance coverage or pay a penalty.

headline: Photos: Mark Vonnegut's Carriage House
summary: The 63-year-old son of late-author Kurt Vonnegut transformed a rotting carriage house that once housed horses for a nearby inn into a home, furnishing it with beds, mantles and bookshelves he made himself and decorating it with mementos of his father.

headline: Four Start-Up Tips From 'The Social Network'
summary: The movie may be a fictionalized account of how Facebook started, but it offers real-life lessons for entrepreneurs.

headline: Why a Bad Jobs Report May Be Good for Stocks
summary: Investors believe a weak September jobs report Friday from the Labor Department wouldn't necessarily be unwelcome. In a twist of logic, negative economic snapshots could lift stocks on hopes central banks might unleash additional stimulus more quickly.

headline: Photos: Private Properties
summary: A Los Angeles mansion that features 11 bedrooms, 14 bathrooms and a Turkish hammam in 48,000 square feet has sold for $50 million. Also, the NFL's Nick Buoniconti has cut the price of his home in Coral Gables, Fla., by 18%.

headline: Renault's Improving Grip on Road
summary: Renault is one of the cheapest but riskiest bets on the global auto sector. Investors are excited, but need to keep their enthusiasm in check.

headline: Deficit Seen Slightly Below $1.3 Trillion
summary: The federal government recorded a budget deficit of just slightly less than $1.3 trillion in fiscal 2010, the second-worst mark since 1945, the Congressional Budget Office said.

headline: Finra Panel Orders Lincoln to Pay $4.3 Million to Investors
summary: Lincoln Financial Advisors must pay more than $4.3 million to a group a 22 investors who accused a manager at the firm of "selling away."

headline: Single-Story Living
summary: Tour one-story homes in Santa Fe, N.M., Seattle and Massachusetts.

headline: From Aussie to Yen to Franc, Dollar Sinks
summary: Expectations the Fed would resume adding cheap money to the system pounded the dollar, which fell which hit a 27-year low against the Australian dollar, a 15-year low against the Japanese yen and a record low against the Swiss franc.

headline: IMF Chief Warns of Currency Battles
summary: Strauss-Kahn backed U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner's call for linking a faster pace of yuan appreciation in Beijing to progress on IMF governance reform to strengthen the voice and vote of emerging economies.

headline: BHP Says Saskatchewan's Potential Tax Loss Is Overstated
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd. said Thursday that a key report issued earlier this week overestimated the potential tax loss the province of Saskatchewan would suffer if its purchase of Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan went through, and underestimated the long-term benefits.

headline: Web Tool Could Help Boost Union Voter Turnout
summary: The AFL-CIO rolled out a website Thursday that gives voters an easy way to identify companies in their zip codes that have outsourced jobs, a tool that could be used to boost the turnout of union households that traditionally back Democrats.

headline: Micron Swings to Profit
summary: Micron Technology swung to a profit on sharply higher revenue and margins, but the memory-chip maker said demand for its two major products is softening.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 7
summary: In Thursday's pictures, men pay homage to their ancestors in Mumbai, stunned children are treated after bombings in Pakistan, an athlete gives it her all in the hammer throw in India and more.

headline: J.P. Morgan Sells $1.1 Billion Commercial-Mortgage Bond
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase sold $1.1 billion of commercial-mortgage securities Thursday in the largest transaction of its type since the financial crisis.

headline: Take Me In to the Ballgame
summary: The Twins' postseason appearance this year is their eighth in the last quarter-century, but it's their first over that period that won't feature perhaps the quirkiest of all major-league parks: the Metrodome.

headline: Boeing Adds 104 New Aircraft Orders
summary: Boeing Co. said its received 104 orders for new commercial aircraft in the week ended Tuesday, bringing the total this year to 392.

headline: Foreign Makers Top 'Green Car' List
summary: As auto makers move to produce cars that use less gas and emit fewer pollutants, foreign-based car companies are edging out American rivals. But U.S. auto makers are catching up, according to a new study.

headline: Betfair Sets Wide Range for IPO
summary: Online sports-betting company Betfair set a price range for its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange at $17.48 to $22.25 a share, valuing its equity at up to $2.35 billion.

headline: Southwest Airlines Posts Higher Demand for September
summary: Southwest Airlines Co. reported continued growth in September as a rebound continues in the travel and tourism sector.

headline: Two Fed Officials Speak Out Against Stimulative Action
summary: Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher said additional asset purchases by the Federal Reserve to stimulate a sluggish U.S. economy are not "a foregone conclusion." Kansas City Fed President Thomas Hoenig said such measures aren't needed.

headline: Pimco Scoops Up TIPS on Bets Fed Will Prevent Deflation
summary: Pimco has scooped up Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities at a time when speculation has grown that the Fed will step up government-debt purchases,

headline: Interest Builds in Pacific Free-Trade Zone
summary: Malaysia says it has joined early talks on expanding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, an effort to tie economies along the Pacific into a free-trade zone that could serve as a counterweight to China's economic influence.

headline: Gold Pulls Back From Record
summary: Gold futures settled below record levels as a surprisingly upbeat jobless-claims report and caution ahead of Friday's monthly employment data led investors to sell the metal.

headline: U.K. House Prices Tumble
summary: U.K. house prices slumped in September by the largest monthly amount since records began in 1983, the Halifax survey showed, while manufacturing output surged to an almost 16-year high in annual terms.

headline: European Stocks End Flat
summary: Investors in European stocks remained largely on the sidelines ahead of Friday's key U.S. September nonfarm payrolls report, leaving stocks narrowly mixed.

headline: Nobel Prize Winners, Past & Present

summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

summary: Marks & Spencer Group reported accelerating quarterly sales driven by fashion and food purchases but warned the consumer outlook is likely to become more challenging.

headline: Statoil Seeks $853 Million
summary: Norwegian oil giant Statoil said it hopes to raise up to $853 million when it lists its Fuel & Retail unit in Oslo on October 22.

headline: Hungary Cleans Toxic Red Sludge
summary: The toxic red sludge that burst out of a Hungarian factory's reservoir and inundated three villages reached the mighty Danube after wreaking havoc on smaller rivers and creeks.

summary: Rail operator Eurostar said it will invest $1.11 billion in its fleet, including a contract for Germany's Siemens to build 10 new sets of trains—a move that provoked protests from the French government and Alstom.

summary: Allied Irish Banks said it will raise about $2 billion from the sale of its 22.4% stake in U.S. regional lender M&T Bank.

summary: Three big technology companies are backing a bill that would strengthen federal protection of privacy on the Internet, amid mounting concerns about the collection and use of personal data.

summary: Austerity measures proposed by Portugal's government to reduce the budget deficit will cause the economy to stagnate next year, the Bank of Portugal said in its quarterly economic bulletin.

headline: BOE Keeps Policy on Hold

headline: U.K. Pension Changes Sought

headline: India, Russia to Sign Pact on Fighter Jets

summary: India's food inflation edged lower after rising for five weeks, but still remained at alarmingly high levels as floods in some parts of the country choked supplies.

summary: Walt Mossberg finds Ford's touch-screen dashboard to have clear, logical displays. But the interface has so many options it presents a learning curve.

summary: Amazon.com is planning to open a software-applications store for smartphones running Google's Android operating system, putting it in competition with Google's own marketplace.

summary: Costco posted a 16% increase in its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings as a rise in net sales and membership fees offset higher costs.

summary: The dollar came under pressure again amid expectations that the Federal Reserve will expand its quantitative-easing policy.

summary: Your editorial "The 'Pay for Delay' Rap" (Oct. 5) correctly states why an outright ban on pay-for-delay is imperfect public policy.

summary: California's natural-gas pipelines spring thousands of leaks each year and the state's gas utilities are cited for scores of violations. But the companies rarely pay penalties allowed under state law, even when accidents kill or maim people.

headline: Sorry, Randy, You Get No Bye Week
summary: Randy Moss could play in 17 games this season, and Tim Lincecum of the San Francisco Giants has some grass-roots support.

summary: Your editorial, "Shakedown in the Rain Forest" (Sept. 23), raises important issues regarding how claims of fraud in foreign courts should be resolved.

summary: The western world is not pulling out of recession with any great vigor. The IMF is clear why—and that resonated with the U.K. Conservative Party's conference in Birmingham.

summary: John C. Goodman's "How Seniors Will Pay for ObamaCare" (op-ed, Sept. 23)eminds me of Alexander Hamilton's dictum: "In the legislature, promptitude of decision is oftener an evil than a benefit."

summary: Crude-oil futures settled at a fresh five-month high after a government report showed a drop in U.S. fuel supplies.

summary: Long-term mutual funds had an estimated $3.26 billion of inflows for the week ended Sept. 29, but outflows from stock funds continued. Money funds shed assets.

summary: Mexican David Alfaro Siqueiros may be best known for his political works on murals, but his technique was refined as an easel painter.

summary: Worries over the risk of combining the blockbuster blood thinner Plavix with certain heartburn pills may be overblown, a new study suggests.

headline: Alcoa Story Likely a Third-Quarter Prologue
